narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot about all varieties of unsupervised learning techniques. Also some experience with pytorch.

This course was a great primer to a lot of different topics ranging from dimensionality reduction to artificial better generation. After having taken this class I feel like I have a new set of tools that I can use when I approached me large and complex data sets that may not be easy to analyze using traditional methods. This class also change the way that I look at data, and have expanded my theoretical understanding of how that that is distributed.

Gained an understanding of a large number of unsupervised learning methods. We especially covered graphs and graph signal processing a good amount. The psets were very helpful for learning how to implement the algorithms we talked about in class.
A broad overview of unsupervised learning techniques in areas like dimensionality reduction, clustering, graph signal processing, & neural nets.
Knowledge of dimensionality reduction, clustering, and neural network techniques among many other things.
Got a broad overview of the theory behind and implementation of various data visualization, clustering, neural network, and other unsupervised learning techniques.
Dimensionality reduction, unsupervised learning, data visualization and context

Visualization techniques such as principal component analysis (PCA), diffusion maps, tSNE, and PHATE. Clustering techniques like k means and spectral clustering. Unsupervised learning neural networks such as autoencoders, variational autoencoders, and generative adversarial networks (GAN). Also learned a little about RNN's and CNN's.

A lot of unsupervised learning techniques broadly organized into 3 categories of visualization, clustering, and "learning".

Visualization: Diffusion maps, PHATE, tSNE

Clustering: Spectral, Louvain, other community detection methods

Learning: A little bit of info theory, GANs, RNNs/LSTMs, VAEs

Quite a lot
Basic dimensionality reduction techniques for large data, coloring and grouping techniques, neural networks and other network models

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is really strong in its course material, but its homeworks are lacking. The undergrad ULA is amazing and incredibly smart, but there should be absolutely zero classes at Yale with an ULA making a problem set. Either the grad TA should be making them or the professor herself. Problem sets are long and they change two days before the due date, even though they take an average student probably 20-30 hours to complete. I cannot emphasize enough how much the psets detract from the rest of the course. Psets are terribly long and not optimized for learning, in the sense that much of it is going back and forth in a jupyter notebook trying to interpret what the pset is even trying to say. Instructions are vague, clarifications are desperately needed and often given 1-2 days after questions have been asked, and in general the psets give the sense that whoever made them doesn't really care about the students.

This course had a perfect amount of material, and the content was delivered in a nice order that built upon each different step. I think that to take it to the next level, it would be nice to see more live demonstrations of the techniques, or more examples included it in the slides. Also, sometimes the math notation was confusing, and so introducing some of the symbols (specifically the more complex probability related ones) might be helpful for students who dont have that background.

Smita's lectures are very strong and I learned a ton of interesting content. That said, I have a relatively surface-level understanding of many topics thanks to the extremely wide range of material covered by the course. Reducing the breadth of the class would help students understand concepts in greater depth. Also, the problem sets were monstrously long. While this isn't terrible in and of itself, it's unrealistic that Smita wants students to completely them *and* do the supplemental readings posted for each class.
Topics are interesting, but prof could do a better job explaining

The problem sets did solidify understanding by providing concrete examples of what we were working on. 

Some of them were difficult to understand, though, and needed lots of clarification from Piazza. They also were often very tedious and I felt like I sometimes spent more time figuring out library syntax than learning.

The strengths of this class are the problem sets. The problem sets are very detailed and allow you to learn how to apply the material presented in lecture. Also, the papers you can read are very good at explaining things that are unclear during lecture. Another strength is that we cover a lot of exciting material and techniques in the class which are extremely applicable to a lot of research topics. Another strength is that the final project in the class allows you to explore whatever material you want, and present it in the form of an ML research paper. Extremely cool, and a lot different than assignments in a usual CS class.

The weakness of this class is definitely that the second problem set was extremely long and taxing, with not a lot of knowledge gained. I would definitely have preferred a problem set on CNN's or RNN's because that was the coolest topic and the coverage of it was rushed at the end of the semester.

Strengths: So many modern techniques that are super cool. Professor Krishnaswamy is also a GOAT. Also, the TF and ULA worked their butt off to give everyone individual customized feedback, which is pretty nuts for a ML assignment. Very rarely do I find a course where it feels like the instructor and teaching staff put in more work into the course than their students, but this is one of those courses, and it really shows in the learning experience imo.

Weaknesses: it's a lot of work

Problem sets were way too long! Having only 3 with parts of them having errors and / or not being covered in class until nearer the due date made it difficult to plan consistent work; splitting them up into more problem sets that are smaller would be much better.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that this course did a great job at adapting to the online situation. Virtual problems set work hours were held, and the teaching staff was always easy to get in touch with.
Both live and recorded lectures was nice
Most of the class was just virtual lecture, which was fine. I liked the system for homework feedback and think it should be kept even without COVID.
I enjoyed the fact that there was recorded lecture because I had an overlapping class. I wish there were some set office hours rather than them only being available through scheduling by appointment.
I thought everything was great

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Kind of. The course material is amazing and it's such a strong plus to have a grasp on what's being taught. The techniques the professor goes over are cutting edge and powerful. However, the problem sets are so shockingly bad that I can't really give a definite yes here. They are raw and filled with inaccuracies and vague questions. This might not be so bad, unless (as is the case here) psets are also already unnecessarily long and tedious. So extremely tedious. I'd actually recommend cr/d/f for this course and just boot half of each pset (there's bound to be 2/3 of each that will cause you extreme frustration to do) and go to lectures and focus on learning the material.

I would recommend this course to any student who is not scared of math, and is interested in expanding the computer science repertoire into the area of unsupervised learning. I personally was not very strong in the prerecs, but was able to understand enough to do all of the problem sets without any problems. And still walk away with a large improvement in my theoretical understanding of the concepts we talked about in class.

This was probably one of the more difficult courses I've taken at Yale, but also definitely worth it. I came in with little knowledge of machine learning and without having ever taken any CS classes, but it was manageable with enough time put in. Definitely very relevant for analyzing biological data and any large data in general. I've found that after this course I've been able to understand many more analyses and computational papers. Towards the end of the semester, we had a third pset, final project, and final exam all clustered around the same time though, so the workload is more end-heavy.

Absolutely - it's super interesting, the psets are good coding practice, and Smita is a stronger instructor than the other Yale faculty who teach machine learning. That said, students should be prepared to have this class dominate their semester academically.
Yes! Excellent coverage of many different topics
Its a good introduction to unsupervised learning, and Professor Krishnaswamy does a lot of cool work thats worth seeing.

Extremely cool class! If you're a CS major who has a bit of background in ML, definitely take this class. It's one of the most rewarding classes I've taken at Yale. 

If you don't have a lot of experience with ML, maybe consider taking S&DS 365 or Computer vision before trying this course. I would have been extremely lost without prior experience in these classes.

A LOT of time was spent on the problem sets, so make sure you're not taking a heavy workload along with this class.

Heck yes! The class is SO cool, Professor Krishnaswamy is SO nice and flexible, not to mention top of her field. If you're interested in ML, this class is for you! The class also almost exclusively focuses on frontier work, and you just feel in awe the more you learn. Really great stuff, probably the best class I've taken at Yale.
Is a good overview course for some very powerful and popular machine learning techniques, definitely learn how to plan out the workload and space it out!
